Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Strong tests of life history theory using experimental reduction of embryo energy content in diverse marine invertebrates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists studying the evolution of life history strategies examine trade-offs between traits to understand how natural selection acts to maximize reproductive success. One fundamental trade-off occurs between the size and number of offspring: an organism can produce many small offspring, or just a few large offspring. There is a large body of theory explaining how these strategies affect reproductive success, but in animals, tests of this theory have been done in only two groups: vertebrates and sea urchins. The proposed research uses experimental embryological techniques to test theory in a much more diverse suite of animals, including members of two of the three major lineages of bilaterally symmetric animals: deuterostomes (hemichordates and echinoderms) and lophotrochozoans (annelids, flatworms, and molluscs).

The proposed work integrates research and education at two institutions focused on providing meaningful student research experiences. The grant will support the development of a series of web-based lesson plans that will be made available for adoption by any institution of higher learning. These lesson plans will be developed through a series of pilot programs run during introductory and upper level biology classes at both institutions. The grant will provide direct support for 8-10 undergraduates and one graduate student, while lesson plans will provide in-class research opportunities for hundreds of additional students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addressed fundamental questions about the life history strategies of diverse marine invertebrates. The animals in this study exhibit complex life cycles with bottom-dwelling adults that produce eggs, embryos and larvae that develop for many weeks in the water column as morphologically distinct offspring. The work sought to answer questions about the role that maternal investment plays in determining offspring success both during the larval stage and post-metamorphosis.

 

We found that in sea stars, unlike in their relatives the sea urchins, maternal investment played a relatively small role in determining larval and juvenile success. Instead, larval food supply was by far the most important factor in determining critical life history traits such as time to metamorphosis, size at metamorphosis and survival post-metamorphosis. In addition, we found that size at metamorphosis was critical for determining the outcome of post-settlement interactions such as juvenile feeding on mussels and, surprisingly, cannibalistic encounters between newly settled sea stars.

 

We also made important discoveries about the way that diverse animal phyla develop and respond to their environment. For example, we found that contrary to existing reports the success of a highly predatory flatworm species is driven in large part by larval access to adequate food resources. This finding has major implications for efforts to reduce eutrophication in Chesapeake Bay where high nutrient levels can increase phytoplankton abundance, thereby increasing recruitment of flatworms. Flatworms in turn are major consumers of juvenile oysters and may be 'blooming' in the Bay as a result of increased phytoplankton abundance. We also found that mud snails, which are abundant all along the east coast of the US and are invasive in parts of the west coast of the US, owe some of their tremendous numerical abundance to an ability to be phenotypically plastic in response to predator cues. In particular, we found that snails deposit their egg capsules strategically off of the bottom of the ocean to prevent encapsulated offspring from being consumed by crab predators. Since many snail species engage in egg deposition behavior, this work has ramifications for the ecology of snails across many habitat types, especially species that rely on limited substrate (e.g. eelgrass in the case of mud snails) for their reproduction.

 

Overall the scientific outcomes of the project were substantial and diverse. The work on our initial goals included surprising discoveries about the way that seastars can overcome variable investment by mothers in their offspring. The work on diverse animal phyla beyond seastars revealed surprising discoveries about the reliance of larvae on phytoplankton food sources and the ability of mothers and embryos to respond plastically to changes in the environment. 

 

The products of the work include: 2 published works, 5 publications that are in preparation for publication, the training of 12 undergraduate students and one masters student, 12 student presentations at 5 national meetings, 3 best student presentation awards, several small grants to student researchers and outreach efforts to elementary school students and coastal landowners in Virginia and Maine.
